p: Although a high incubation temperature of 60°C contributed to a marked increase in sialidase activity and improved detection sensitivity ( Fig 1B), it has been reported that there were differences in the temperature-activity profile and thermostability between sialidase activities of IAV and IBV [ 46]. Increased sialidase activity in a high temperature condition needs to be confirmed for IAV (H3N2) and IBV, as well as A/Puerto Rico/8/1934. In order to examine the optimal incubation temperature for BTP3-Neu5Ac reaction, we incubated IAV and IBV with 100 μM BTP3-Neu5Ac in the temperature range from 37 to 70°C in the presence of 50 mM CaCl 2 for 10 min. As shown in Fig 2, within the range of 37 to 60°C, sialidase activity of A/Puerto Rico/8/1934 was temperature-dependently increased, being consistent with the data shown in Fig 1B. On the other hand, for A/Memphis/1/1971 and B/Lee/1940, the sialidase activities were greatly decreased at a temperature higher than 58°C. These results suggested that 56°C, but not 60°C, was the most appropriate temperature to enable sialidase detection of both IAVs (H1N1 and H3N2) and IBV.
